column1: HTMG1010 is an introductory course that takes a macro-level view of the hospitality, tourism, and real estate industries. The contents are geared towards students who have little to no industry experience but have expressed an interest in pursuing a career in the industry or a related field.The primary objectives of this course are three-folded. First, this course discusses the historical developments, business models, and management structures of lodging, restaurant, managed service, casino/gaming, meetings / conventions / expositions, recreation, club, theme park, cruise, airline, and other hospitality and tourism organizations. Second, experiential learning opportunities are provided to help students understand the operations of hospitality organizations and the importance of service quality. The course also introduces students to the business world of real estate, including terminology, transaction process, issues, players and activities in the real estate industry. Third, the course prepares students for future development of leadership competencies with descriptions of the key management functions and the characteristics and practices of leaders and managers. Students will also learn about some of the most important business / tourism ethics principles and corporate social responsibilities.

To keep abreast of the development that affects current managerial practices, industry executives of the hospitality, tourism, real estate and service related industries are invited as speakers to address the opportunities and challenges facing their respective fields. These courses provide a unique opportunity for successful industry leaders to share their visions, experiences and views regarding successful management styles, critical industry-related issues, identify career paths and offer career aspirations to the students in the programme.

An international experience is a personal and professional growth opportunity for students to interact with a culture other than their own, to improve their cultural understanding, and to prepare for working more effectively in diverse cultural and business environments. International experience has been shown to increase graduates’ employability. It is particularly important in global industries such as the hospitality and real estate industries where communication skills, problem-solving skills, and service orientation are crucial for career success. This course is designed to encourage students to participate in international experience activities prior to graduation. These activities include overseas exchange, internship, study tour, volunteer/service learning projects, and other international learning activities.

This is a course that examines the principles of food and beverage management. It begins with an overview of the food service industry and the specific disciplines of food service distribution. Current issues in food safety and sanitation procedures that affect managerial decisions in hospitality industry will be discussed. Detailed considerations are given to the components of the food service system: marketing, menu planning, purchasing, logistical support, guest service, controls, and quality assurance. Students will also learn through visits to restaurant operations, analyse the restaurant's concept (market), organization, ownership, management, physical structure, staff, front- and back-of-the-house operations, and fiscal integrity.

In order for students in the Major to apply theory to application, they are required to gain hands-on experience and to participate in industry-related internship experiences throughout their study, preferably during two summers. Summer Internship I is a course to monitor students in their first summer internship training. The educational objectives can be achieved through industry activities that are either operational based and/or project based. The Internship Program allows students to gain a realistic expectation of the hospitality and tourism operations. All internship experiences must be approved by the School. Thus, for students who choose to self-place, it is his/her responsibility to seek prior written approval from the Director before the internship begins.

This course introduces students to the principles of hotel management. It contains an overview of organization, function, and management of lodging operation. The discussion will focus on the inter-relationships among stakeholders of a lodging facility - guests, managers, owners and employees. Special emphasis will be on the integration of the various departments of a hotel facility, i.e. Rooms, Front Desk, Sales, Food and Beverage (F&B), Purchasing, Housekeeping, Engineering and Maintenance, etc., to ensure customer satisfaction while maximizing the return on investment. Students will be exposed to computing applications specific to the hotel industry. Hotel security, guest safety as well as total quality issues will also be discussed.

All organizations are faced with “people issues.” Why do people think, feel, and act in certain ways in the workplace? How do you manage people effectively to achieve the organizational objectives? More important, how do you continue to manage people effectively when the organization is going through significant strategic/structural changes? This course draws upon the theoretical insights and empirical evidence from the Organizational Behavior (OB) research and introduces students to the applications of psychological and behavioral approaches to designing effective human resource management (HRM) policies and practices. The course provides a systematic overview of fundamental OB concepts, theories, and applications in the context of hospitality, tourism, and real estate businesses. We will discuss a variety of topics at three levels. First, we will study how individuals differ in their personality traits, values, attitudes, emotions, perceptions, and motivations. Second, we will examine how people interact with one another and work in groups and teams. Topics range from team dynamics, group decision making, power and influence, to conflict management. Leadership theories and practices will also be discussed. Third, we will discuss how organizational-level factors such as organizational culture and change affect attitudes, behaviors, and work performances of employees. The OB concepts and theories are closely related to HRM. Through the course students will learn how to apply OB theories to improve HRM effectiveness in a variety of areas, e.g., job design and analysis, employee recruitment and selection, training and socialization, employee performance appraisal, compensation and benefits, and organizational culture formation and maintenance. Students will also learn what characteristics, behaviors, attitudes, and competencies define good leadership and how to ensure successful organizational changes through effectively motivating employees. Overall, this course explains why and how individuals and groups are motivated to do their jobs and helps students develop critical leadership skills to manage people and organizational changes.

This course is designed to encourage students to think about hospitality properties as real estate. The two fundamental markets that are relevant to commercial real estate investment analysis are space market and asset market. The former refers to the market for the right to use real estate (e.g., land and buildings) and the latter refers to the market for the ownership of real estate assets. This course focuses on the space market. Specific objectives are: to recognize the importance of real estate space market in the overall real estate system, which involves an understanding of supply, demand and rent in the space market; to understand the fundamental factors of location of economic activities; and to learn real estate market analysis for providing advice to real estate decision makers.

This course seeks to provide an introduction to the institutions, doctrines and methodology of the law in the context of the hospitality business. To this end, the course will begin with an examination of the legal system of the Hong Kong SAR before proceeding to encompass a selection of topics in business and hospitality law such as the law relating to contract,agency, employment and the sale of goods and torts (e.g., negligence and occupier's liability).

Knowing laws that govern the hospitality and real estate industries is no longer a luxury. It is a knowledge that every manager must acquire to protect their companies from unnecessary fines, lawsuits and negative publicity. This module focuses on the laws relating to the hospitality and real estate industry in Hong Kong. It provides students with the essential knowledge on legal principles that are important for the practice within the hospitality and real estate industry. The course will introduce a wide range of legal topics including legal system, company law, contract law, tort law and land law.

This course is an overview of the travel and tourism industry's management issues, professional opportunities, marketing concepts, planning and development strategies and its relevance to the geography of travel, transportation issues and travel service. Different aspects of tourism, including origin and destination flow models, tourist profiles, demand and supply interaction, and barriers to travel are explored and analysed. Emerging concepts such aseco-tourism, heritage tourism, adventure tourism, sustainable tourism, etc., will also be examined.

Hospitality is a service industry which heavily rely on effective service management for competitive advantage. Service management is a well-established academic field which recognize service through integration of technology, operations and human behaviour. This course emphasizes the uniqueness of service management applicable to the hospitality industry and the need for continuous improvement in quality to ensure competitiveness in a global environment. Topics include understanding of the new service economy concept, service strategy with data analytics and application of IoT in hospitality industry. Students will evaluate services designed through UX interface, analyze hospitality service operations, discuss the disruptive impact of technology and take part in innovate a service system/process applicable to the hospitality industry.

This course focuses on managing people in the workplace. It addresses issues of human resources planning and staffing and substantive issues or situations to be faced as future hospitality managers, including the relationship between selection and recruitment, compensation and benefit activities and job design, motivation, and reward structure. Students will also learn the major theoretical and practical issues associated with programme design,development, implementation, and evaluation of hospitality human resources programme.

This course exposes students to concepts, theories and industry practice in real estate finance which is one of the largest and most important components of the financial system. It also introduces valuation and appraisal methods used for real estate finance and investment decision making. The primary goal of this course is to help students acquire the knowledge and develop the analytical skills of real estate finance, including the institutions and instruments used to finance residential and commercial real estate. It is of particular use to students who are interested in working the real estate development, brokerage, mortgage banking and investment banking industries. The main topics covered in the course are mortgage products, mortgage banking, secondary mortgage market and mortgage-backed securities (MBS), financial leverage and commercial real estate finance.

This course applies accounting, finance, and cost control principles to the hospitality industry. The focus of this course is to provide future hospitality managers with the ability to add value and to handle the unique problems regarding financial management and cost control in this industry. Special emphasis will be placed on the estimation of cash flows and asset management related to the hospitality industry. It also provides a detailed analysis of food,beverage, and labour cost control.

Owing to the fact that becoming skilled at training and development is no longer a function of just human resources professionals, managers and leaders are responsible for the training and development of their employees also. This course is designed to facilitate students’ understanding of the frameworks and conceptual underpinnings of training & development (T&D), and their application of the latest human resources development tools and techniques in addressing T&D issues. The formulation and implementation of effective policies, systems and programs for the T&D of manpower at all levels of the hospitality operations are emphasized.

This course provides a basic understanding to students on collection, processing, analysis and applications of marketing data in the service industry. The course is divided into two parts, namely, Customer Relationship management (CRM) and Marketing Research. CRM covers the recent trend in data driven marketing and social media marketing to use secondary data (e.g. customer transaction data, internet data) to understand customers, and design strategies to sell the right products to right customers at the right time. Marketing Research covers the traditional survey methodology and the use of primary data to support decision making in marketing. Our approach to CRM and marketing research is more on the concept, design, and applications instead of mathematics or statistics. No formula is required to understand the material, and students use Excel in data analysis. Moreover, we will invite experts from the industry to share the current practices of marketing research and CRM in both Hong Kong and China.

Course approaches the cruise industry as a unique combination of the hospitality, tourism, marketing and shipping industries. Course objectives are designed to familiarize students with the structure and operation of the cruise industry and related leisure/tourism segments of overnight and fast ferries; river cruises; sail cruises; gaming boats; and passenger/cargo operations. Having successfully completed this course, students will be able to understand the evolution of the modern cruise industry and the factors involved in its growth, to identify the market segments and their relationship to itinerary, onboard product and ship design; to know the major cruise lines and their target markets and operating areas; to be familiar with the impact of ship design constraints, SOLAS (Safety of Life at Sea) and MARPOL (Maritime Pollution Regulations), and other regulatory requirements on onboard product, itinerary, and ship cost and finance. Also, students will become familiar with cruise trends and innovations.

Wine has its roots customs, traditions and history. It occupies an important place in culture and life of people worldwide. Starting in the 1990s, there is a great surge of interest in wine across the globe. Wine has been a significant element in social gathering and business meetings. Wine becomes the challenge for hospitality operators to meet the needs of increasing sophisticated tastes of consumers. To be an effective hospitality manager, knowledge of the alcoholic products, particularly wine, is essential. The ability to taste, understand, evaluate, and articulate wine in a clear, easily understood manner is key to meeting customers' needs and at the same time, increasing wine sales and profitability. The course is designed to expose students wine label terminology, wine appreciation, and learn the principles on how to choose wines to pair with many different foods. The topics include cultural history of wine, the role of alcohol in society; major wine regions, grape varieties, vintages and winemaking process, sensory training and comparative tasting methods to help build students' ability to discern distinct flavours from major types of wine and build strong base for lifelong wine appreciation and enhance their quality of life.

The commercial aviation business contributes significantly to the global economy in general and the hospitality and tourism industry in particular. Airlines generate direct financial opportunities to airports, aircraft manufacturers (OEMs), ground handling companies, flight catering operations, aviation related organizations, etc. Furthermore, the aviation industry also plays a key commercial role in the travel and tourism ecosystem, working closely with the hotel and restaurant sectors, the attractions, the travel intermediaries, the land and sea transport operators, plus many other tourism related businesses.This course will provide an introductory overview of the commercial passenger airline and airport business, focusing on the management aspects of the businesses. The contents include aviation regulatory principles, airline alliances and cooperation, revenue management, loyalty management, distribution management, marketing, network planning issues, business aviation (private jet in Asia), airport and FBO management, intermodal transportation, and contemporary issues of the airline business.

Shopping mall business is an attractive business in Hong Kong. There are many leading shopping malls in the region and it generates stable rental income and attractive returns to the property developers. Property developers differentiate their shopping malls from their competitors and it forms a significant part of investment (called investment properties) on the Statement of Financial Positions and has significant impact on the Income Statement. This course aims at introducing students to the management and investment perspective of shopping mall business and how it contributes to tourism. It includes design of a shopping mall, its marketing, leasing process, customer services, car park management, investment return analysis, investment value calculation and the regulatory framework. Ethical considerations facing property developers and investors will also be discussed. After taking this course, students should have good understanding of the shopping mall business and allow them to work in the real estate management and investment field.

This course introduces both the theory and the practice of revenue management. Revenue management (RM) is the process of improving corporate revenue through the implementation of demand forecasting, strategic pricing and inventory/duration control. In a simple way, the concept of revenue management is to sell the right product to the right customer for the right price at the right time and through the right channel. In this course, we will focus on the important elements leading up to effective revenue management – market segmentation, differential pricing, demand forecasting, inventory control, distribution channel management and performance evaluation. RM has been a data and analytics heavy driven discipline. Students will be exposed and learn to apply various analytics techniques for revenue/price optimization.

Land improvement refers to investments that make land more usable for humans. Prior to the development of its industrial and commercial activities, Hong Kong was once an agrarian society with a large amount of active agricultural land. The growth of Hong Kong’s economy is accompanied with large areas of agricultural land, with fish ponds and farmlands, being developed into other uses. Land conversion process and development control has significant economic and social implications for all stakeholders involved. This course is designed to address two major topics: lease control and statutory control during land conversion and development processes. The course provides a foundation for understanding land development. Landowners and developers of all sizes typically aim to maximize profits, minimize risks and control cash flow. These objectives require landowners and developers to design optimal plans for local markets and meet local legal and administrative requirements and procedures. This course introduces Hong Kong’s land tenure system and development control and helps students understand the geographical characteristics of real estate properties in Hong Kong that have been developed into different uses over time. Students will also learn about the interplay between development processes and local conditions.

This course provides the most fundamental concepts, principles and techniques useful for making investment decisions regarding commercial real estate assets. Important subjects such as discounted cash flow (DCF), net present value (NPV), valuation of property price, use of debt and tax investment analysis will be covered. Adequate time will be dedicated to learn how to build a fully integrated property financial model which is the most typical analytical tool to evaluate investment performance and help decision making. Students will walk through the financial details relevant to a property and create five-year/ten-year cash flow projections. Familiarity with excel will be a requirement of this course. To enhance the mastery of the lecture and improve applications to real world practice, a number of case studies and practical exercises that help to reinforce the financial modelling techniques necessary for financial decision making will be selected.

Hospitality is about engaging people through friendly, genuine experiences. Today, the notion “hospitality” has gone beyond lodging and food & beverage businesses and been recognized as a key aspect of many other types of service businesses, e.g., tourism, retail, healthcare, recreation, or even real estate and property management services. Moreover, hospitality is not just about creating memorable, “front-of-the-stage” customer experiences. It is also about creating warm, welcoming, “back-of-the-stage” work experiences for employees. With “experience” as a central theme, a key question for organizations is “How to create the best experience for customers as well as employees?” This course prepares students to answer this question by applying Design Thinking methodology to hospitality experience design for customers and employees in service businesses. Design Thinking is a process for creatively and systematically solving problems by putting people and their needs first. It emphasizes deep understanding of user experience and empathetic, iterative, and non-linear processes of imagination and idea generation. In this course, students will learn about the fundamental design thinking processes and tools and apply them to practical projects aimed to incorporate the notion of hospitality in design thinking for hospitality and real estate businesses. Students will work in teams on projects assigned by a service business for the purpose to design/improve customer and/or employee experiences in specific operational areas. Students will be guided through the processes of understanding experiences, building empathy with customers/employees, defining problems, collecting and analyzing data, generating solutions, and testing solutions. You are expected to develop a deeper understanding of hospitality spirit from a design thinking perspective, gain hands-on experience in service design tasks, enhance problem-solving abilities, and improve teamwork and communication skills.

The evidence-based policy and practice is of importance in real estate field. The best evidence, which can only be derived from an excellent research, is not only to enhance our understanding, but also to convince others. In the real estate practice, people may ask, “Does the household income affect the property price?” “Should a property located at higher floor command higher price?” The answer can be “yes” or “no” due to a number of factors affecting the price of a property. The empirical evidence is thus needed to convince others.This module focuses on quantitative methods in real estate. It provides students with the fundamental knowledge on conducting real estate research that involves analysis of quantitative data. This course introduces a wide variety of quantitative techniques and tools to analyse the property price. Key topics include hedonic pricing model, managing data, regression analysis and forecasting.

This course provides students with a strong foundation in the conceptualization and operationalization of research, how to design a research project and ‘hands-on’ skills in the utilization of different research methods. Students will be exposed to a wide range of qualitative and quantitative research methods. Topics to be covered in qualitative research methods include sampling, collection techniques (e.g. in-depth interview, focus group interview, content analysis, etc.) and interpreting qualitative data (e.g. qualitative data analysis procedures and coding). Topics to be covered in quantitative research methods include sampling methods, data collection instruments, survey development, descriptive statistics, inferential statistics (e.g. t-test, regression, analysis of variance, correlations, chi-square, etc.), and data mining. Intellectual and methodological debates will be discussed in order to assist students to develop informed opinions and a critical appreciation for other’s research.

This course provides an in-depth understanding to students on how hospitality companies can effectively manage and design customer experience online and offline to foster long-term customer relationships. Main topics include the unique characteristics of services and value co-creation; how to evaluate the service process using design thinking tools; how to engineer authentic and memorable customer experience with design thinking methodologies; how to handle customer complaints and perform service recoveries; and how to develop omnichannel strategy to engage with customers.

This course is centered on a theme-based five-day or one-week overseas study trip to a selected destination. Students are expected to explore local hospitality/tourism business practices and examine the multi-dimensional impacts of the increasingly global hospitality/tourism industry on local community and environment. The course is designed to increase students’ international and experiential learning opportunities. Destinations and themes may differ across academic terms when the course is offered. In principle, the course addresses both exploratory and analytical/evaluative themes. Exploratory themes may cover such issues as local culture, food, hospitality/tourism trends, hospitality history, eco-tourism, heritage tourism, local events/festivals, to name just a few. Analytical/Evaluative themes, on the other hand, require students to understand and evaluate local hospitality/tourism organizations’ practices in areas such as sustainable (“green”) operations, branding/marketing, service quality management, business strategies, and/or corporate social responsibility initiatives. The trip aims to help students gain in-depth and context-specific knowledge of industry practices. In terms of pedagogical methods, the course consists of pre-trip, during-trip, and after-trip learning activities. Pre-trip seminars prepare students for a better understanding of the theme and the destination. Field trips, company visits, and/or local university visits are arranged during the trip. Students are required to keep a travel journal and also complete a group report documenting their findings and thoughts about the study theme. Overall, this course integrates traveling with learning, seeing with thinking, knowledge of global operations with awareness of local contexts. Through learning and sharing, students are encouraged to reflect on their own values and experiences, develop a deeper sensitivity to cultural diversity, and form a better understanding of how hospitality/tourism affects local environment, economy, and culture.

In order for students in the Major to apply theory to application, they are required to gain hands-on experience and to participate in industry-related internship experiences throughout their study, preferably during summers. Summer Internship II is a course to monitor students in their second summer internship training. The objectives of the internship program are to 1) To provide management training opportunities for students to apply what they have learned in the classroom to solving real-world business problems related to the hospitality and tourism industry; 2) To develop a good understanding of the different aspects of the hospitality and tourism operations in Hong Kong and abroad; and 3) To strengthen and build character and instill professional attitude and passion in students towards the hospitality and tourism industry. Students will develop their analytical and problem solving skills by assuming the role of the manager, to offer probable recommendations/solutions to the operational problem that they encounter in the internship. All internship experiences must be approved by the School. Thus, for students who choose to self-place, it is his/her responsibility to seek prior written approval from the Director before the internship begins.

This course is a continuation course of HTMG3523 Introduction to Real Estate Investment. In this course, a review of the financial modelling techniques and how to apply them to analyze development projects will be covered. A particular topic will focus on the financial analysis of real estate development (the market that links the space market and the asset market in a dynamic real estate system). Developing real estate is a high risky investment, to determine a project’s viability; feasibility study must be carried out, which include a comprehensive analysis of the property development process from initial financial evaluation through construction to final sale. Students will use the acquired financial modelling skills and through the application of market research and intelligence to develop credible feasibility reports.

This course discusses marketing strategies of service firms, new marketing approach, and reformulation of traditional marketing principles. It will also address issues related to international marketing with emphasis on the hospitality and tourism industry.

This is the 7th course in the series. To keep abreast of the development that affects current managerial practices, hospitality, tourism and service-related executives are invited as speakers to address the opportunities and challenges facing their fields. Students learn from the industry leaders their visions, experiences and views regarding successful management styles, and critical industry-related issues. In addition, students are required to research and analyze the background of the executives and their companies regarding the company history, mission and philosophy, culture and strategy. They will gain valuable insights from best practices in the industry and at the same time, to reflect on career aspirations and identify their own career paths.
